title: 110_s2774
content: The Act titled "Federal Judgeship Act of 2008" may be cited as such. It includes provisions for circuit judges for the circuit courts of appeals. The "Federal Judgeship Act of 2008" authorizes the President to appoint additional circuit judges for various circuit courts of appeals, with specific numbers allocated for each circuit. Additionally, temporary judgeships are provided for the ninth circuit court of appeals. The "Federal Judgeship Act of 2008" authorizes the appointment of additional circuit judges, with specific numbers allocated for each circuit. Temporary circuit judgeships created by this act shall not be filled after 10 years. The table in title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent circuit judgeships authorized. The "Federal Judgeship Act of 2008" authorizes the appointment of additional circuit judges, with specific numbers allocated for each circuit. The table in title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent circuit judgeships authorized. Number of judges per circuit: District of Columbia - 11, First - 7, Second - 15, Third - 16, Fourth - 15, Fifth - 17, Sixth - 17, Seventh - 11, Eighth - 13, Ninth - 33, Tenth - 12. The Tenth Circuit has 12 judges. SEC. 3. DISTRICT JUDGES FOR THE DISTRICT COURTS. The President appoints additional district judges for various districts, including Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Indiana, and Minnesota. Additional district judges are appointed for various districts including Missouri, Nebraska, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, South Carolina, Texas, and Minnesota. In addition to the appointment of district judges in various districts like Missouri, Nebraska, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, South Carolina, Texas, and Minnesota, there are plans to appoint additional district judges in Alabama, Arizona, California, Colorado, and Florida. Additional district judges are proposed for the southern district of Florida, district of Idaho, northern district of Iowa, district of Nevada, district of New Jersey, district of New Mexico, district of Oregon, and district of Utah. The first vacancy in each district occurring 10 years after a judge is confirmed to fill a temporary judgeship created by this proposal will not be filled. Existing judgeships in certain districts will be authorized under section 133 of title 28, United States Code, with the incumbents holding office as amended by this Act. The existing judgeship for the northern district of Ohio authorized by the Judicial Improvements Act of 1990 shall be extended, and the first vacancy in the office of district judge occurring 20 years after the confirmation date of the temporary judgeship created shall not be filled. The table in section 133 of title 28, United States Code, will be amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent district judgeships authorized. In Alabama, there are 13 judges in total across the Northern, Middle, and Southern districts. Alaska has 3 judges, Arizona has 17 judges, and Arkansas has 8 judges in the Eastern and Western districts. California has the most judges with a total of 70 across the Northern, Eastern, Central, and Southern districts. Colorado has 8 judges. Colorado has 8 judges. Connecticut has 8 judges. Delaware has 4 judges. District of Columbia has 15 judges. Florida has 3 regions with different numbers of judges. Georgia has 3 regions with varying numbers of judges. Hawaii has 4 judges. Idaho has 2 judges. Illinois has 22 judges in the Northern region. Illinois has 22 judges in the Northern region. Indiana has 5 judges in the Northern region and 6 judges in the Southern region. Iowa has 2 judges in the Northern region and 3 judges in the Southern region. Kansas has 6 judges. Kentucky has 5 judges in the Eastern region, 4 judges in the Western region, and 1 judge in both the Eastern and Western regions. Louisiana has 12 judges in the Eastern region and 3 judges in the Middle region. Massachusetts has 13 judges, Michigan has 15 judges in the Eastern region and 4 judges in the Western region, Minnesota has 8 judges, Mississippi has 3 judges in the Northern region and 6 judges in the Southern region, Missouri has 7 judges in the Eastern region, 6 judges in the Western region, and 2 judges in both the Eastern and Western regions. New York has 56 judges divided into Northern, Southern, Eastern, and Western regions. North Carolina has judges in Eastern and Middle regions. Ohio has 11 judges in the Northern region and 8 judges in the Southern region. Oklahoma has judges in the Northern, Eastern, and Western regions. Oregon has 7 judges. Pennsylvania has 22 judges in the Eastern region, 6 judges in the Middle region, and 10 judges in the Western region. In Tennessee, there are 3 regions with 5 judges in the Eastern, 4 judges in the Middle, and 5 judges in the Western region. Texas has 4 regions with 12 judges in the Northern, 21 judges in the Southern, 8 judges in the Eastern, and 14 judges in the Western region. Utah has 5 judges. Utah has 5 judges. Vermont has 2 judges. Virginia has 12 judges in the Eastern region and 4 judges in the Western region. Washington has 4 judges in the Eastern region and 8 judges in the Western region. West Virginia has 3 judges in the Northern region and 5 judges in the Southern region. Wisconsin has 5 judges in the Eastern region and 2 judges in the Western region. Wyoming has 3 judges. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes funding for judicial positions and facilities. The Act, along with its amendments, will be effective on January 21, 2009, following a coordination rule with another related law.
